intro: Agalinis fiebrigii, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically blooms in the summer months, producing pink to reddish hues that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open habitats like grasslands and disturbed areas. Agalinis fiebrigii is a short-lived perennial that plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
